chucho
@Ittai glad to have you on board with us! It was great watching and supporting Constitution DAO. Do you think we could use Juicebox for this project? What were your learning using that tool?
Ittai 04-Dec-21 07:13 PM
To keep it short, I think it's wise to build a custom solution and pay for third party auditing, rather than using a one-size-fits-all solution, because this DAO will almost certainly need to handle unique operations that won't be supported. The primary case for using Juicebox or Juicebox competitor is when optimizing for blazing speed, like we were with ConstitutionDAO (had ~6 days total).
chucho
@Ittai glad to have you on board with us! It was great watching and supporting Constitution DAO. Do you think we could use Juicebox for this project? What were your learning using that tool?
Ittai 04-Dec-21 07:14 PM
In the case of this project, we don't have an external deadline of ~1 week, and we should have access to devs and auditors (myself included), to do this right. (edited)

Let's talk governance. IMO, token-voting is a terrible governance mechanism. I'd suggest that Hyperscale creates an expert council instead. https://vitalik.ca/general/2021/08/16/voting3.html
Moving beyond coin voting governance
3
The challenge is to create governance that is trustworthy (e.g. collusion-resistant) yet efficient

Hello future | Hedera
The trust layer of the internet is here

Paul | KILT Protocol 04-Dec-21 10:30 PM
The problem with councils is that they become ripe with nepotism. Which makes sense you recruit people who can be effective council members... so you end up recruiting your peers and the interest becomes centralised. I'm a fan of councils as longs as there's effective means of ensuring diversity. Gitcoin's quadratic voting is interesting as well especially if you can protect against bots.

@miles : Can you explain how the Hedera council works? Their document explaining the council just says that new members are chosen by "objective criteria" determined by the other members.
miles 04-Dec-21 10:36 PM
Members must have a minimum $10 billion market cap to join the Hedera council. There will be up to 39 members, each with 3-year term limits
The council is distributed by geography and industry
miles
Members must have a minimum $10 billion market cap to join the Hedera council. There will be up to 39 members, each with 3-year term limits
robiosss 04-Dec-21 10:36 PM

ibab 04-Dec-21 10:37 PM

miles 04-Dec-21 10:38 PM
It's all about trust. These members are building applications on Hedera and have brands to protect. The goal behind the Hedera council to prevent forks while enabling future upgrades to various Hedera services
Governance is critical to security
Imagine if Coinbase forked USDC to a new version of Ethereum
Ethereum would get f**cked

vishalr 05-Dec-21 12:29 PM

has there been discussion/channel around how we will use AI? i’m thinking before end-to-end decision making, we can frame this in few sub-problems 1. how do we match applications with relevant investors? this can be as simple as explicit industry fields in the application, and can go as deep as intent/tonal NLP once this scales. 2. what additional context can we provide investors to decide fast? this could include mining from news sources to say “five web3 startups are exploring this space” and from the application “the founders have deep expertise” and “decent growth for seed stage” 3. how will decision-making look like right now? few expert-led? what level of community involvement? surface data to everyone or private recommendations? these questions would influence the objective function and the system as a whole. @kevalin i know AI isn’t in v1 but would be nice to spin off a channel and do framing / data exploration till then. niftynewbie
Repeating a few thoughts from the call: we want to leverage the strengths of web3 rather than build a tokenized version of web2. What are the bottlenecks today that can be overcome by web3? One example would be that funding is given and funds are moved but startups are just sitting on that capital, should we consider staking the investments and only move the fund that’s required every month?
nicklinck 05-Dec-21 02:39 PM
Other advantages of web 3 is that equity can be defined on chain, and code is generally open sourced (hence forkable). It would be cool/"more fair" for open sourced projects, if we could set up an event where once a project is forked, the equity owners of the first project are given equity in the new project (their equity could dilute over time). To incentivize the "forkers" to agree to this model, we could offer funding to the forkers. The newly forked projects might also tend to be better deals since they are building on something that works and they think they have a way to improve it.

One idea - we have a company here in Canada called Clearco. It provides small loans to early stage companies, using AI to help refine the criteria. The loans are paid back with interest as the companies generate cashflow. LZRS 05-Dec-21 06:59 PM
AI-DAO hybrid approach * Get a reasonable amount of data from the founders * Use the DAO/community to generate a large amount of analyst reports * Train the AI on the the founder data AND analyst reports * Compensate analysts (edited)
4
I think this works because it generates crowd wisdom by sourcing analysis from many members of the community. However, it is hard to parse so much data quickly. AI can then step in. In other words, this could theoretically allow for more diligence than the top investment firms and 10x speeds.
Basically the whole process can be done in the time that it takes to write 1 analyst report. because all reports are done in parallel and AI makes the decisions.
It also generates sufficient data for AI to become useful and is not onerous for the founders
i think this is a better way for community input than voting, for instance. But definitely I would like to hear other alternatives
d3sm0

d3sm0
as an ml engineer what i read here is you give some features about the project / team and the crowdsourced likelihood of investing from the community, the more the ai matches the prediction of the community the larger is the amount of deal flow that the dao can handle. Is that correct?
LZRS 05-Dec-21 07:42 PM
Not exactly. Let me try to explain it better: 1) The founder applies for funding 2) The application is distributed to analysts (DAO participants) 3) The analysts write free-from reports 4) AI decides buy/sell based off of analyst reports (with access to historical track record data) This takes advantage of the distributed nature of DAO relative to a traditional investment firm. It parallelizes the diligence process so the number of applications the DAO can process scales proportionally the number of participants in the DAO. Also quality of investments have a positive correlation with number of participants. It also allows the DAO to have a built-in moat--a network of analysts.
Sam is already considering analyzing free form content (most likely with open ai tech) https://discord.com/channels/916751469678579784/916751469678579787/916799708557635605

i like to thinnk about how can we use the structure of this DAO as an advantage against traditional VC firms. We can deploy lots of people to write reports. They won't be as good individually as analyst reports from top investment firms, but they will scale much much much better
there is literally no limit to the amount of scaling that our dilligence efforts could have. and the more participants, the better for the AI. And the time that dilligence takes would not scale with the number of analysts, since it is completely parallelized
if every analyst publishes their report to their own hyperscaledao newsletter (like substack, i.e. lzrs.hyperscaledao.com), they can also generate inbound interest via content marketing (edited)

Ryu 05-Dec-21 08:29 PM
Get every investment idea out in the open
Community members can publicly stake an imaginary position
Very common in finance; helps to train the next gen of portfolio managers. You get the prospective successors to paper trade and see how they would do without real-world market friction
And without real $ at stake. If they suck at paper trading they're not going to be any better in practice.

mmm I'm aware of different VC that uses or built ML tools for driving their investment strategies, but i believe it is mostly quantitative analysis, i.e. market, sectors, product category and some other kpi like someone was saying about e-commerce. This part should be trivial, especially because most of these projects might live in the web and on-chain too. The tricky bit is to capture the same "wisdom" that a16z/YC/etc.. after having seen and talked and checked with countless founders, matched with a strong prior about the status of the tech/market and people. That's where @sama99 comment on looking at conversation and videos kicks is because the question is how to train an AI which has less understanding about the economics of the world and people, to make decisions that are at least as good as the top investment firms in a fraction of the time. One answer could be imitation, as the DAO can act as synthesize al the prior information about the market status and gut feeling on teams.

LZRS 05-Dec-21 08:37 PM
I think it's important to resist the urge to overly formalize the structure of the data. I don't think that will work. I don't believe there are a list of X number of criteria through which you can assess an early stage company. It's the details that matter. We likely won't be able to come up with a good feature list relative to what unsupervised learning can provide. And some of these things can be very subtle. I think it's best to just let people write their reports as they wish and stay away from frameworks and spreadsheets, if that makes sense.

Harbs 06-Dec-21 08:36 AM
Thinking about the value add and there are a few different approaches worth exploring. An obvious starting point would be to leverage the DAO community in these ways:
1
1. Community led marketing: leveraging all members of the DAO to announce new investments, project launches, to acquire users for betas etc. via social and WOM. Effectively marketing reach that can be leveraged at no cost. 2. Community building: allowing projects to share open source task lists with the DAO so our members can help propel progress. With intensive help for 3-4 weeks alone, a project could progress at an unparalleled rate - this is a pull factor for projects to work with DAOs. 3. User feedback: feedback from the DAO can be shared to help with product direction, test new functionality, and identify bugs. The speed at which a project can iterate will be increased massively if a pool of members are always available. *This thread of logic where we leverage the power of the network can extend across use cases. This is really unique to DAOs. 4. Cross-project exposure: projects that take investment could receive a proportion of tokens in a subDAO that is tied to all of the investments made in their year of investment or in the DAO. Projects would benefit from the outcome of all projects the DAO has invested in and this should uniquely build community, collab between projects, and security. 5. Shared expertise: structuring the network of DAO members by their expertise and making this searchable should allow projects to access domain experts. This is done at YC and TechStars, and is always valuable but more traditional i.e. it wouldn’t be a unique feature a DAO can provide. (edited)

zsyver 08-Dec-21 03:47 AM
If ownership is denominated in tokens, there is a real legal case for it to simply be another form of equity. That being said, if that ownership is not publicly traded, then it will have representative power within the organization as a whole (and buying/selling aforementioned representative ownership can occur privately). The creation of new, deep liquid markets will get the SEC interested especially if there are statements of "performance" or "return on investment" involved.
zsyver

fr3klz 08-Dec-21 04:10 AM
obviously you avoid that language at all costs, but the reality is, how do you keep the community incentivized if there's no financial gain to be made?
zsyver 08-Dec-21 04:22 AM
For the investors, they put down real cash (actual companies will be made once they determine they like one by voting for one). For the ones who are operationally active, they spend their time and allocate or receive equity based upon the organizational agreement for contributors. If this is followed, a real company could be fully funded through this private arrangement and then abide by normal SEC rules if it files to go public. As long as private ownership is clearly stated and agreed upon internally, there ain't much the SEC can do. 'Murica.

nicklinck 09-Dec-21 09:51 PM
had a v2 / v3 thought today inspired by how quickly we were able to build a company... We don’t just invest. We build startups a website, the design of their company, provide a marketing strategy, and legal setup for your startup. Some of our people can continue to work on it, but now you have funding to hire out a team. You are the project lead, you keep ~25-51% of the company (because we did significantly more for this investment now). would require many more resources but maybe each time we are able to execute on an idea like we did for hyperscale, we can curate a data set that will allow AI to do this much faster! Not just scaling funding, but scaling startups to what they would normally be in 3 months, in only 3 days.

You are the project lead, you keep ~25-51% of the company (because we did significantly more for this investment now). would require many more resources but maybe each time we are able to execute on an idea like we did for hyperscale, we can curate a data set that will allow AI to do this much faster! Not just scaling funding, but scaling startups to what they would normally be in 3 months, in only 3 days.

zsyver 09-Dec-21 10:10 PM
This is what I envision for further iteration of a DAO business model. I believe it totally makes sense that all endeavors done under Hyperscale end up contributing to a dataset that can help future communities do the same thing that we set out to do (only faster and better). But the AI model that is trained must be controlled and managed by the architect and the users--not followed blindly.
2
Eric Berry
why do you think support centric firms like a16z haven't deployed a similar model?
nicklinck 09-Dec-21 10:17 PM
I think its vey hard to scale! To bring the required people together was hard when everyone met in offices and tooling wasn't as collaborative. I think firms like a16z got into their habits that have paid off well for them and do not have an incentive to pivot to a new model that will require a lot of effort. But with all of the people on board and potentially collaborations with Open AI (if @sama99 thinks its worth it ) I think we could automate a large portion of this current manual effort in order for it to scale!

zsyver
For the investors, they put down real cash (actual companies will be made once they determine they like one by voting for one). For the ones who are operationally active, they spend their time and allocate or receive equity based upon the organizational agreement for contributors. If this is followed, a real company could be fully funded through this private arrangement and then abide by normal SEC rules if it files to go public. As long as private ownership is clearly stated and agreed upon internally, there ain't much the SEC can do. 'Murica.

zsyver 14-Dec-21 03:22 AM
Actually, it would work but it'd have to be very small. It's clearly an impractical scenario (but technically feasible for very small groups [<30 from what I've read] even without accredited investors). The SEC wouldn't look at a 30MM+ membered DAO that says it's "private" and have nothing to say. But at a small level, even a verbal agreement can be considered a contract. Part of the reason I'm interested in understanding the legality and feasibility of a lean and mean DAO is the implications it could have on this project (Hyperscale) and the implications it could have on simplifying/decentralizing the early development process. Imagine having an internal measurement to automatically tell the team that it's time to file XYZ based upon ABC metric and previous DAOs' experience? There's huge potential for transfer learning in something like this.
